column1: Jaraguá do Sul (26°29′10″S 49°04′00″W) is a city located in the north of the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina.
The city was founded on July 25
column2: 1876 by engineer and Brazilian Army colonel Emílio Carlos Jourdan and his family. The city was originally named just Jaraguá
column3: but it was later renamed to Jaraguá do Sul due to a city already named Jaraguá in Goiás state.

column1: Jaraguá means Lord of the Valley in a Tupi–Guarani language. It was the name given by the indigenous population of the city to the Boa Vista Hill (Morro da Boa Vista).
It borders Campo Alegre and São Bento do Sul to the north; Blumenau
column3: Pomerode and Rio dos Cedros to the south; Guaramirim
column4: Joinville and Schroeder to the east and Corupá to the west.

column1: The Itapocu River is Jaraguá do Sul's important river
column3: being Jaraguá River and Itapocuzinho River its main affluents.

column2: with average annual temperature around 21 °C. In summer temperatures often exceed 35 °C
column3: although they may reach 40 °C in a few days. The winter is relatively cold for Brazilian standards
column4: with an average minimum temperature around 12 °C in the months of June and July. Frosts occur almost every winter. Zero temperatures are rare
column5: and that mark was reached most recently on July 14
column6: 2000. The lowest temperature occurred on July 19
column8: when thermometers recorded −2 °C. The highest temperature ever recorded was 42.5 °C on January 3

column1: The local economy is mainly based in metallurgy and clothing industries. The city was the origin for several worldwide companies
column2: like WEG (electric motors and industrial electronics)
column6: Menegotti (construction equipment) and many others. The city is the 3rd largest economy of the state.

column1: Jaragua do Sul is home to the Festival de Musica de Santa Catarina which was created by Alex Klein.  The festival is held in late January and attracts students and faculty from all over the world. The program involves faculty and students recitals
The Schützenfest (also known in Brazil as Festa dos Atiradores) is a traditional festival held annually since 1988
column2: celebrated in October in Jaraguá do Sul. It is part of the popular festivals celebrated in that month in Santa Catarina state due to the German colonization in the region.

column1: The first inhabitants of the city were the indigenous people of the Xokleng and the Kaingang. Later the following ethnic groups immigrated to the city: Germans
column6: which were brought to the city as slaves.
